image.altText: A crowd of people search desperately through a collapse building and rubble in the street

items.synopsis: It is unclear why buses arranged to transport Australian citizens from the West Bank have been delayed, while Israel's military says four people killed on the Lebanon border were part of a "terrorist squad". Follow live.

title.children: Buses for Australians evacuating West Bank delayed, IDF says four 'terrorists' killed near Lebanon border

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Hamas's head of international relations Dr Basem Naim says the terrorist group's plan was never to target civilians when militants attacked Southern Israel on October 7. "The chief commander of the Al Qassem Brigade, who initiated the operation, he gave clear instructions not to target civilians or not to harm civilians," he told ABC's 7.30. "In the middle of the confrontation, there was some civilians. The clear instruction was not to kill civilians." The Hamas leader also claimed there were no plans to take civilian hostages. "We haven't planned at any moment to take any civilian hostages. The plan was to take on the fight against soldiers and to take some soldiers as hostages." Pressed on whether he was claiming the terrorist group had lost control of its fighters, Dr Naim told 7.30 that others had infiltrated the Hamas operation. You can read the rest of the story below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: A Hamas leader says there were no plans to target civilians or take hostages

featuredLink.title: Hamas senior leader says there were no plans to target civilians in Israel attack

children.content: Hamas's head of international relations Dr Basem Naim says the terrorist group's plan was never to target civilians when militants attacked Southern Israel on October 7.
"The chief commander of the Al Qassem Brigade, who initiated the operation, he gave clear instructions not to target civilians or not to harm civilians," he told ABC's 7.30.
"In the middle of the confrontation, there was some civilians. The clear instruction was not to kill civilians."
The Hamas leader also claimed there were no plans to take civilian hostages.
"We haven't planned at any moment to take any civilian hostages. The plan was to take on the fight against soldiers and to take some soldiers as hostages."
Pressed on whether he was claiming the terrorist group had lost control of its fighters, Dr Naim told 7.30 that others had infiltrated the Hamas operation.
You can read the rest of the story below:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The United Nations human rights office says Israel's siege of Gaza and its evacuation order there could amount to the international crime of "forcible transfer of civilians". Ravina Shamdasani, a spokesperson for the UN human rights office, says Israel seems to have made no effort to ensure civilians temporarily evacuated in Gaza were provided with proper accommodation, as well as satisfactory conditions of hygiene, health, safety and nutrition. "We are concerned that this order, combined with the imposition of a complete siege of Gaza, may not be considered as lawful temporary evacuation and would therefore amount to a forcible transfer of civilians in breach of international law," she says. "Those who managed to comply with the Israeli authorities' order to evacuate are now trapped in the south of the Gaza Strip, with scant shelter, fast-depleting food supplies, little or no access to clean water, sanitation, medicine and other basic needs." The term "forcible transfer" describes the forced relocation of civilian populations and it is a crime against humanity punishable by the International Criminal Court (ICC). Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israel's Gaza evacuation order could amount to crime of 'forcible transfer of civilians,' UN says

children.content: The United Nations human rights office says Israel's siege of Gaza and its evacuation order there could amount to the international crime of
"forcible transfer of civilians".

Ravina Shamdasani, a spokesperson for the UN human rights office, says Israel seems to have made no effort to ensure civilians temporarily evacuated in Gaza were provided with proper accommodation, as well as satisfactory conditions of hygiene, health, safety and nutrition.

"We are concerned that this order, combined with the imposition of a complete siege of Gaza, may not be considered as lawful temporary evacuation and would therefore amount to a forcible transfer of civilians in breach of international law," she says.

"Those who managed to comply with the Israeli authorities' order to evacuate are now trapped in the south of the Gaza Strip, with scant shelter, fast-depleting food supplies, little or no access to clean water, sanitation, medicine and other basic needs."
The term "forcible transfer" describes the forced relocation of civilian populations and it is a crime against humanity punishable by the International Criminal Court (ICC).
Reuters

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Family members of Mia Schem and representatives of the Hostages and Missing Families Forum have spoken to the media after the release of a video by Hamas that they claim shows Mia Schem in captivity. Hamas released the video on Telegram of the 21-year-old, who is understood to be held hostage following a music festival. It is not known when or where the video was recorded. Mia's mother Keren Schem told the press she did not know if Mia was alive or dead until she saw her on the TV. "I am begging the world to bring my baby back home, she only went to a party, to a festival party to have some fun. And now she is in Gaza and she's not the only one," she said. "This is a crime against humanity and we should all gather and stop this terror. And bring everybody back home." Keren told the press, sitting between two of Mia's brothers, that her child had other medical issues and needed urgent care. Keren said her message to her daughter was: "I love her so much, and I miss her so much and all these days I am thinking about hugging her when she's coming home and that's what keeps me strong and focused." Israel's military says the group is holding 199 hostages in Gaza. Hamas says it has between 200 and 250.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Family of Mia Schem address the press after release of Hamas hostage video

children.content: Family members of Mia Schem and representatives of the Hostages and Missing Families Forum have spoken to the media after the release of a video by Hamas that they claim shows Mia Schem in captivity.
Hamas released the video on Telegram of the 21-year-old, who is understood to be held hostage following a music festival.
It is not known when or where the video was recorded.

props.alt: Keren Schem holding a photo of Mia in front of press microphones.

children.content: (AP: Ohad Zwigenberg)
Mia's mother Keren Schem told the press she did not know if Mia was alive or dead until she saw her on the TV.
"I am begging the world to bring my baby back home, she only went to a party, to a festival party to have some fun. And now she is in Gaza and she's not the only one," she said.
"This is a crime against humanity and we should all gather and stop this terror. And bring everybody back home."
Keren told the press, sitting between two of Mia's brothers, that her child had other medical issues and needed urgent care.
Keren said her message to her daughter was:
"I love her so much, and I miss her so much and all these days I am thinking about hugging her when she's coming home and that's what keeps me strong and focused."
Israel's military says the group is holding 199 hostages in Gaza. Hamas says it has between 200 and 250.

image.altText: A person with dark skin wearing a beanie with their head resting in a their hand.

items.synopsis: The grief-stricken grandmothers of a First Nations teenager clinging to life after apparently trying to take his own life inside a notorious youth detention unit say they feel like he was "sent to a big meat house and came back slaughtered".

title.children: 'He had dreams': Heartbroken family of 16yo on life support say he just wanted to return home

image.altText: Five people standing in a asia grocery store. Man in the middle wearing red tinged glasses.

image.altText: a man named Michael Landis with a young child strapped to his chest stands next to his wife at Sydney airport

image.altText: Four Perth Glory players huddle in celebration on the pitch during a night game.

title.children: Four months after being placed in receivership, Perth Glory has a new owner

image.altText: girl in tent

items.synopsis: Sixteen-year-old Maddison's family pays $360 a week to live in a tent after having to move out of their rental home when it went up for sale. The teenager has big dreams, but she worries about her future.

title.children: Maddison and her family live in a tent. Her parents say they can't afford the fuel to drive her to school

image.altText: A photo of police and a handful of people in civilian clothing lined up to pay their respects.

items.synopsis: A magistrate in Western Australia's north condemns a recent assault on police, with the number of attacks against officers in the Kimberley region increasing by more than 50 per cent in 12 months.

title.children: Assaults on police in the Kimberley jump 50pc, as magistrate details impact on officers

image.altText: The main street of a rural town

title.children: Almost 90 per cent of people in this WA farming town voted No. Here's why

image.altText: An old colour photo of a young man sitting in bushland with no shirt on

items.synopsis: A coronial inquest into the 43-year-old's death has heard he told a close friend he was in trouble before mysteriously going missing in 2021.

image.altText: Naomi Watts wearing a white shirt and sunglasses with short blonde hair

image.altText: Peter Greste speaking at the National Press Club

image.altText: Dominic Perrottet, Scott Morrison

image.altText: Dwayne Johnstone, with his step-mother, father and partner

title.children: Defence argues 'reasonable grounds' for fatal shooting as correctional officer tried for murder

image.altText: A man and woman shake hands.

items.synopsis: Fiji's Prime Minister Sitiveni Rabuka uses a speech in Canberra to call for a "Zone of Peace" in the Pacific, urging the US and China to step back from their intensifying contest for influence in the region.

image.altText: Couple standing on a rocky landscape.

title.children: Australian man's romance lands him in the middle of Israel-Gaza war

image.altText: Vladimir Putin emerges from a pack of men in suits, looking proud of himself

items.synopsis: Vladimir Putin is making a rare visit to China for his "dear friend" Xi Jinping's Belt and Road summit. Seen as something of a social pariah on the global stage, and facing war crimes charges over his assault on Ukraine, what do he and Xi stand to gain from this visit?

title.children: Putin has landed in one of the only places he won't be arrested. Here's what he and Xi could be looking to achieve

image.altText: A man stares down the barrel of a camera while sitting in a room, wearing all black.

items.synopsis: Alex Ophel, who is facing two charges of attempted murder for allegedly stabbing two women at the Australian National University, will undergo psychiatric assessment before his case returns to court.

image.altText: Injuries to a police officer following an alleged assault.

image.altText: A defaced electoral sign.
